title: Shock pictures show right-wing protesters being brutally attacked by anti-fascists
text:
Shock pictures show right-wing protesters being brutally attacked by anti-fascists Shock pictures show right-wing protesters being brutally attacked by anti-fascists PROTESTERS clashed with riot police during a row over refugee children attending a Greek primary school. PUBLISHED: 22:30,  42, Mon, Feb 20, 2017 
Violence erupted outside the school in Oreokastro as nine refugees went to lessons in the suburb north of Thessaloniki. 
Local media reported members of the right-wing Citizens of Oreokastro took part in the fighting. 
A member of the patriotic group was reportedly taken to hospital after being beaten by an anti-fascist campaigner. 
Dozens of riot police surrounded the school as the refugee children were seen walking to a school bus. Related articles GREECE BURNS: Masked attackers PETROL BOMB left-wing ruling party's HQ Dozens of riot police surrounded the school as protesters clashed outside 
Witnesses told Greek media protesters shouted at the children as they left the school as chaos hit the streets. 
It comes after campaigners tied themselves to the school railings on Friday over the refugeesâ€™ attendance. 
Masked thugs were caught on film hitting a protester with batons and kicking a man to the ground. AFP GETTY Right-wing protesters clash with anti-fascists in Greece AFP GETTY A masked thug attacks with a glass bottle AFP GETTY Masked attackers armed with poles and glass bottle attack in Oreokastro 
One man was seen wielding a spade as others used metal poles and glass bottles as violence gripped the town. 
A member of the Citizens of Oreokastro was seen wearing a neck brace and a bandage around his head following the violence. 
The row in the northern Greek town began when children from a local refugee centre were granted permission to be taught at the school. 
Police were seen grappling with protesters wearing baseball caps and covering their faces with scarves. AFP GETTY Riot police hold back protesters AFP GETTY Protesters clash outside the school in Oreokastro 
More than 100,000 refugees have arrived in Greece since January last year, with 2,053 arriving in January and February 2017, according to UN figures. 
The majority of refugees in Greece have come from Syria with the numbers dropping since the Balkan route to Europe was closed off last year. 
The violence comes as protests kicked off in Athens over the living conditions for refugees at a camp in Eleonas. Greek migrant crisis
